data.text: @tombergk I do suspect we'll have to go further

@OYCar @theosanderson So it seems — lots of virologists worry it will do just the opposite 🤷‍♀️ I just feel one should not use an entire nation as testing ground. Not to mention that more than a fair share of otherwise provax people are not convinced enough to participate...
@tombergk @theosanderson So they’re betting the house on the vaccine. I hope it works.
@tombergk @theosanderson No fast test and Boris bringing in “Papiere, bitte” seem unlikely.

@tombergk @theosanderson So you need efficient testing plus strict measures once transmission is a tiny fraction of what is seen in Europe. So I’m worried that after a long period of normalisation a be dangerous variant is going to overwhelm the health service.
@OYCar @theosanderson If we had some rapid antigen tests at home and would require to have a negative test in pocket in order to exit house then I think it would be a game changer.

@tombergk @theosanderson Australia where I am has had very efficient testing but very loose restrictions most of the time. We seem to cope with about 1 case per million people per day. Beyond that it gets hairy.
@OYCar @theosanderson I think you can have less strict measures if coupled with efficient testing — too bad UK has failed to roll out massive rapid testing everywhere.
@theosanderson @tombergk It could take Wuhan like measures to do that. Which seem implausible in the UK. So is there any other option?
@theosanderson I mean our lockdown in March/April was less strict than in many places is Europe even...
@tombergk Totally endorse the lockdown but it's not clear that the measures of March/April will achieve R<1 (from SAGE, and also just looking at the R value then)

I understand why political leadership is behind any decision that could keep the economy going and avoid a proper lockdown but why are a number of scientists and epidemiologists supporting this? Surely they know there are NPI options on the table. Or am I missing sth 🤔
